title: 110_s585
content: The "Native American $1 Coin Act" is the short title of the Act. It establishes the Native American $1 Coin Program. The Native American $1 Coin Act amends Section 5112 of title 31, United States Code, to authorize the redesign and issuance of circulating $1 coins honoring Native Americans and their contributions to US history starting in 2009. The coins will feature the 'Sakakawea design' on the obverse and a design on the reverse selected according to specific requirements. The Native American $1 Coin Act mandates design requirements for the $1 coins, including images celebrating Indian tribes and Native Americans' contributions to US history on the reverse, and the inscription '$1' and 'United States of America' on the reverse. The obverse design will be chosen by the Secretary after consulting with the Commission of Fine Arts. The Native American $1 Coin Act mandates design requirements for the $1 coins, including the 'Sakakawea design' and the inscription 'Liberty'. The year of minting, 'E Pluribus Unum', and 'In God We Trust' shall be edge-incused into the coin to preserve its distinctive edge. The Native American $1 Coin Act mandates design requirements for the $1 coins, including the 'Sakakawea design' and the inscription 'Liberty'. The year of minting, 'E Pluribus Unum', and 'In God We Trust' shall be edge-incused into the coin to preserve its distinctive edge. The reverse designs for the coins are chosen by the Secretary after consultation with various committees and organizations. The Coinage Advisory Committee may depict individuals and events such as the creation of Cherokee written language, the Iroquois Confederacy, Wampanoag Chief Massasoit, the 'Pueblo Revolt', Olympian Jim Thorpe, Ely S. Parker, and code talkers who served the United States Armed Forces during World War II. The Coinage Advisory Committee may depict important Native American contributions on the reverse of $1 coins each year, including individuals like Olympian Jim Thorpe and code talkers who served in the United States Armed Forces during World War II. The design should not depict an individual in a size that could make the coin appear to be a '2-headed' coin. Each $1 coin minted with a design on the reverse in accordance with this subsection for any year shall be issued during the 1-year period beginning on January 1 of that year and shall be available throughout the entire 1-year period. Each coin issued under this subsection commemorating Native Americans and their contributions shall be issued in chronological order until the termination of the coin program. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant committees and organizations, has the authority to determine the issuance of numismatic coins in uncirculated and proof qualities. The number of $1 coins minted each year with a specific design must be at least 20% of the total number of $1 coins. The Secretary of the Treasury must ensure that at least 20% of the total number of $1 coins minted each year feature the "Sakakawea design." Additionally, a marketing program will be implemented to encourage businesses to use and distribute these coins, with an annual report on its success to be submitted to Congress. SEC. 3. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Presidential $1 Coin Program under Section 5112(n) of title 31, United States Code, was amended to redesign beginning in 2007 and change "Sacagawea-design" to "Sakakawea-design". Additionally, barriers to the circulation of $1 coins were addressed in Section 5112(p) of title 31, United States Code. The Presidential $1 Coin Program in title 31, United States Code, was amended to change "Sacagawea-design" to "Sakakawea-design" in paragraphs (3)(C) and (5).
